test_patch:
diff --git a/test/optimizer/statistics/statistics_join.test b/test/optimizer/statistics/statistics_join.test
index 637a96020ed7..74aacecc4f87 100644
--- a/test/optimizer/statistics/statistics_join.test
+++ b/test/optimizer/statistics/statistics_join.test
@@ -67,12 +67,6 @@ EXPLAIN SELECT i1.i FROM integers i1 LEFT JOIN integers2 i2 ON i1.i=i2.i ORDER B
 ----
 logical_opt	<REGEX>:.*EMPTY_RESULT.*
 
-# left join with guaranteed match: same as inner join
-query II
-EXPLAIN SELECT i1.i FROM integers i1 LEFT JOIN integers2 i2 ON i1.i<i2.i ORDER BY 1;
-----
-logical_opt	<REGEX>:.*CROSS_PRODUCT.*
-
 # semi join
 # join cannot match: replaced with empty result
 query II
diff --git a/test/sql/join/left_outer/left_join_issue_6341.test b/test/sql/join/left_outer/left_join_issue_6341.test
new file mode 100644
index 000000000000..3ad233d08b28
--- /dev/null
+++ b/test/sql/join/left_outer/left_join_issue_6341.test
@@ -0,0 +1,37 @@
+# name: test/sql/join/left_outer/left_join_issue_6341.test
+# description: Issue #6341: No rows returned in LEFT JOIN with < or > against table having no rows
+# group: [left_outer]
+
+statement ok
+PRAGMA enable_verification
+
+statement ok
+CREATE TABLE foo (ts TIMESTAMP);
+
+statement ok
+CREATE TABLE bar (ts TIMESTAMP);
+
+
+statement ok
+INSERT INTO foo VALUES ('2023-01-01 00:00:00');
+
+statement ok
+INSERT INTO foo VALUES ('2023-01-01 00:00:01');
+
+query II
+SELECT foo.ts foo, bar.ts bar FROM foo LEFT JOIN bar ON foo.ts = bar.ts;
+----
+2023-01-01 00:00:00	NULL
+2023-01-01 00:00:01	NULL
+
+query II
+SELECT foo.ts foo, bar.ts bar FROM foo LEFT JOIN bar ON foo.ts < bar.ts;
+----
+2023-01-01 00:00:00	NULL
+2023-01-01 00:00:01	NULL
+
+query II
+SELECT foo.ts foo, bar.ts bar FROM foo LEFT JOIN bar ON foo.ts > bar.ts;
+----
+2023-01-01 00:00:00	NULL
+2023-01-01 00:00:01	NULL
problem_statement:
No rows returned in LEFT JOIN with < or > against table having no rows inserted
### What happens?

See repro below.

Note it only occurs with `<` and `>`, but not `=`, so perhaps an ordering issue?

### To Reproduce

```sql
CREATE TABLE foo (ts TIMESTAMP);
CREATE TABLE bar (ts TIMESTAMP);

INSERT INTO foo VALUES ('2023-01-01 00:00:00');
INSERT INTO foo VALUES ('2023-01-01 00:00:01');

.print no rows in bar, no rows returned for < or >:
SELECT foo.ts foo, bar.ts bar FROM foo LEFT JOIN bar ON foo.ts = bar.ts;
SELECT foo.ts foo, bar.ts bar FROM foo LEFT JOIN bar ON foo.ts < bar.ts;
SELECT foo.ts foo, bar.ts bar FROM foo LEFT JOIN bar ON foo.ts > bar.ts;

.print with row in bar works as expected:
INSERT INTO bar VALUES ('2023-01-01 00:00:01');
SELECT foo.ts foo, bar.ts bar FROM foo LEFT JOIN bar ON foo.ts = bar.ts;
SELECT foo.ts foo, bar.ts bar FROM foo LEFT JOIN bar ON foo.ts < bar.ts;
SELECT foo.ts foo, bar.ts bar FROM foo LEFT JOIN bar ON foo.ts > bar.ts;

.print delete row in bar and still works as expected:
DELETE FROM bar;
SELECT foo.ts foo, bar.ts bar FROM foo LEFT JOIN bar ON foo.ts = bar.ts;
SELECT foo.ts foo, bar.ts bar FROM foo LEFT JOIN bar ON foo.ts < bar.ts;
SELECT foo.ts foo, bar.ts bar FROM foo LEFT JOIN bar ON foo.ts > bar.ts;
```


---

```
no rows in bar, no rows returned for < or >:
┌─────────────────────┬───────────┐
│         foo         │    bar    │
│      timestamp      │ timestamp │
├─────────────────────┼───────────┤
│ 2023-01-01 00:00:00 │           │
│ 2023-01-01 00:00:01 │           │
└─────────────────────┴───────────┘
┌───────────┬───────────┐
│    foo    │    bar    │
│ timestamp │ timestamp │
├───────────────────────┤
│        0 rows         │
└───────────────────────┘
┌───────────┬───────────┐
│    foo    │    bar    │
│ timestamp │ timestamp │
├───────────────────────┤
│        0 rows         │
└───────────────────────┘
```

```
with row in bar works as expected:
┌─────────────────────┬─────────────────────┐
│         foo         │         bar         │
│      timestamp      │      timestamp      │
├─────────────────────┼─────────────────────┤
│ 2023-01-01 00:00:01 │ 2023-01-01 00:00:01 │
│ 2023-01-01 00:00:00 │                     │
└─────────────────────┴─────────────────────┘
┌─────────────────────┬─────────────────────┐
│         foo         │         bar         │
│      timestamp      │      timestamp      │
├─────────────────────┼─────────────────────┤
│ 2023-01-01 00:00:00 │ 2023-01-01 00:00:01 │
│ 2023-01-01 00:00:01 │                     │
└─────────────────────┴─────────────────────┘
┌─────────────────────┬───────────┐
│         foo         │    bar    │
│      timestamp      │ timestamp │
├─────────────────────┼───────────┤
│ 2023-01-01 00:00:00 │           │
│ 2023-01-01 00:00:01 │           │
└─────────────────────┴───────────┘
```
```
delete row in bar and still works as expected:
┌─────────────────────┬───────────┐
│         foo         │    bar    │
│      timestamp      │ timestamp │
├─────────────────────┼───────────┤
│ 2023-01-01 00:00:00 │           │
│ 2023-01-01 00:00:01 │           │
└─────────────────────┴───────────┘
┌─────────────────────┬───────────┐
│         foo         │    bar    │
│      timestamp      │ timestamp │
├─────────────────────┼───────────┤
│ 2023-01-01 00:00:00 │           │
│ 2023-01-01 00:00:01 │           │
└─────────────────────┴───────────┘
┌─────────────────────┬───────────┐
│         foo         │    bar    │
│      timestamp      │ timestamp │
├─────────────────────┼───────────┤
│ 2023-01-01 00:00:00 │           │
│ 2023-01-01 00:00:01 │           │
└─────────────────────┴───────────┘
```

### OS:

Linux

### DuckDB Version:

v0.7.1-dev57 8da10c8e33

### DuckDB Client:

CLI

### Full Name:

Dave Tapley

### Affiliation:

JE Fuller

### Have you tried this on the latest `master` branch?

- [X] I agree

### Have you tried the steps to reproduce? Do they include all relevant data and configuration? Does the issue you report still appear there?

- [X] I agree
No rows returned in LEFT JOIN with < or > against table having no rows inserted
### What happens?

See repro below.

Note it only occurs with `<` and `>`, but not `=`, so perhaps an ordering issue?

### To Reproduce

```sql
CREATE TABLE foo (ts TIMESTAMP);
CREATE TABLE bar (ts TIMESTAMP);

INSERT INTO foo VALUES ('2023-01-01 00:00:00');
INSERT INTO foo VALUES ('2023-01-01 00:00:01');

.print no rows in bar, no rows returned for < or >:
SELECT foo.ts foo, bar.ts bar FROM foo LEFT JOIN bar ON foo.ts = bar.ts;
SELECT foo.ts foo, bar.ts bar FROM foo LEFT JOIN bar ON foo.ts < bar.ts;
SELECT foo.ts foo, bar.ts bar FROM foo LEFT JOIN bar ON foo.ts > bar.ts;

.print with row in bar works as expected:
INSERT INTO bar VALUES ('2023-01-01 00:00:01');
SELECT foo.ts foo, bar.ts bar FROM foo LEFT JOIN bar ON foo.ts = bar.ts;
SELECT foo.ts foo, bar.ts bar FROM foo LEFT JOIN bar ON foo.ts < bar.ts;
SELECT foo.ts foo, bar.ts bar FROM foo LEFT JOIN bar ON foo.ts > bar.ts;

.print delete row in bar and still works as expected:
DELETE FROM bar;
SELECT foo.ts foo, bar.ts bar FROM foo LEFT JOIN bar ON foo.ts = bar.ts;
SELECT foo.ts foo, bar.ts bar FROM foo LEFT JOIN bar ON foo.ts < bar.ts;
SELECT foo.ts foo, bar.ts bar FROM foo LEFT JOIN bar ON foo.ts > bar.ts;
```
